title: How to Lower CPK Levels Naturally

steps.title: Try the Mediterranean diet.
steps.content: Try the Mediterranean diet. The Mediterranean diet is a heart-healthy meal plan that limits the intake of salt, bad fats, and red meat. Eating more plant-based foods, like fruits and veggies, as well as whole grains and healthy fats may reduce your risk of heart disease. [2] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Fish are a great source of protein you can eat on the Mediterranean diet.

steps.title: Eat foods that can help lower your cholesterol.
steps.content: Eat foods that can help lower your cholesterol. High cholesterol can put you at risk for long-term issues like heart disease. [3] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Foods that help to lower your cholesterol levels in turn help to prevent heart disease. [4] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source High CPK levels can indicate damage to the heart, so lowering your cholesterol might help prevent further damage. [5] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Foods that may lower your cholesterol include oats, beans, eggplant, okra, nuts, grapes, strawberries, apples, soy, and fatty fish. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Get plenty of omega-3s to improve your muscle health.
steps.content: Get plenty of omega-3s to improve your muscle health. Don’t let the word ‘fatty’ fool you—omega-3 fatty acids are essential nutrients when it comes to having a healthy body. They can help lower your risk of heart disease and increase your good cholesterol levels. [7] X Trustworthy Source Journals of the American Heart Association Open Access, peer-reviewed journals focusing on cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases, as well as related scientific research. Go to source Omega-3 can be found in sardines, mackerel, tuna, salmon, eggs, milk, yogurt, flaxseeds, and nuts. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Lower how much fat and salt you eat each day.
steps.content: Lower how much fat and salt you eat each day. High blood pressure and heart diseases are often seen in conjunction with high CPK levels. [9] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source You can lower your blood pressure by limiting the amount of salt you eat and reducing your fat intake. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eat low-fat or non-fat dairy products like skim milk, low-fat yogurt, and cheese. Avoid very fatty foods like butter, gravies, and lard.

steps.title: Cut back on your protein and creatine intake.
steps.content: Cut back on your protein and creatine intake. Try not to eat as much cooked meat, which contains a lot of creatinine. Additionally, consider cutting back on protein and creatine supplements, which may also cause your levels to go up. [11] X Research source Instead, look for more natural forms of protein, like lentils. [12] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source Eating a lot of cooked meat may show a “false positive,” or high amount of CPK levels in your blood.

steps.title: Remove alcohol from your diet.
steps.content: Remove alcohol from your diet. Drinking alcohol can increase your CPK levels, so eliminate it from your diet or cut back as much as possible. [13] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source

steps.title: Eat more garlic to improve your overall health.
steps.content: Eat more garlic to improve your overall health. Garlic has long been known to promote a healthy heart. It lowers blood pressure and prevents platelet aggregation, both of which can improve your heart health. [14] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Exercise regularly to keep your body healthy.
steps.content: Exercise regularly to keep your body healthy. Aerobic exercise, strength training, and stretching and flexibility all contribute to a healthy body. Aim to exercise for at least 30 minutes a day on 5 or more days per week. [15] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Ask your doctor if high-intensity exercise is causing your CPK.
steps.content: Ask your doctor if high-intensity exercise is causing your CPK. Another common cause of elevated CPK level is strenuous exercise. While regular exercise is encouraged, a sudden increase to the intensity or amount of exercise you do can raise your CPK levels. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Exercises that involve weightlifting and downhill running cause higher increase in CPK levels.

steps.title: Avoid exercising the day before and the day of a CPK test.
steps.content: Avoid exercising the day before and the day of a CPK test. Strenuous exercise is actually a common cause of a falsely elevated CPK level in patients being tested for CPK levels. Because of this, it is important that you don’t exercise the day before or the day of your doctor’s appointment so that you don’t get a false reading of your CPK levels. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Ask your doctor if statins are increasing your CPK counts.
steps.content: Ask your doctor if statins are increasing your CPK counts. Statins are medications that are effectively used to lower blood cholesterol levels. However, one of their side effects is rhabdomyolysis, or breakdown of muscle tissue due to inflammation. [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Because of this mechanism, these drugs cause an elevated CPK level. Types of statins include atorvastatin (Lipitor), rosuvastatin (Crestor), pravastatin (Lipostat), fluvastatin (Lescol), and simvastatin (Zocor). [19] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Be aware that some other drugs can raise your CPK levels.
steps.content: Be aware that some other drugs can raise your CPK levels. Other medications that can increase CPK levels include fibrate drugs and amphotericin B. If you are taking any of these medications, they might be the reason for your elevated CPK levels so you should talk to your doctor about trying different medications to treat your conditions. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Talk to your doctor about changing your prescription, if it’s necessary.
steps.content: Talk to your doctor about changing your prescription, if it’s necessary. If you are taking any of the above-mentioned medications and are having an issue with elevated CPK levels, you might want to consider trying different medications. You can consult your doctor, tell them about your elevated CPK levels, and ask for a revision of your prescription. [21] X Research source If you can’t get a different prescription, your doctor will work with you to find another way to bring your CPK levels down.

steps.title: Get a proper diagnosis if you don’t know the cause of your high CPK.
steps.content: Get a proper diagnosis if you don’t know the cause of your high CPK. Since there are many causes of CPK, it might take a while for your doctor to reach a conclusion. However, some causes of CPK require immediate treatment so that you can preserve your health, so it’s important to get your diagnosis (likely with a CPK test). [22] X Research source Then, talk to your doctor about the treatments available to you. For instance, your high CPK levels could be caused by an injury, an infection, or a prescription medication. However, it could also be caused by a neuromuscular, metabolic, or rheumatologic condition, like arthritis or lupus. Some conditions may worsen if you don’t treat the underlying cause.

steps.title: Check with your doctor before using herbs and supplements.
steps.content: Check with your doctor before using herbs and supplements. While herbs and supplements are usually safe, they’re not right for everyone, especially if you’re taking medications. They might interfere with your medication or worsen your condition. To be on the safe side, talk to your doctor before you start using herbal remedies. [23] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source Remind your doctor of the medications and supplements you’re already taking. Let your doctor know you’re working on lowering your CPK levels naturally. They may have additional advice to help you.

steps.title: See your doctor if you have symptoms of myopathy.
steps.content: See your doctor if you have symptoms of myopathy. Myopathy means that your muscles aren’t working correctly. This may sound scary, but treatments might be available to help you feel better. In some cases, myopathy can cause high CPK levels, as well as other symptoms. Visit your doctor if you notice a combination of the following symptoms, which vary: [24] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Muscle weakness Rash Lung issues Heart disease Muscle imbalance Other muscle issues

steps.title: Get emergency care if you have the symptoms of a heart attack.
steps.content: Get emergency care if you have the symptoms of a heart attack. Sometimes high CPK levels can mean you’re at risk for a heart attack. [25] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Try not to worry because you can get treatment. However, it’s important that you act fast if you may be having a heart attack. Go to an emergency room or call for help if you have the following symptoms: [26] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Chest pain or pressure Shortness of breath Pain that spreads to your jaw, neck shoulder, arm, or back Nausea or heartburn Abdominal pain Fatigue Lightheadedness or dizziness Cold sweat
